1349 Glenn Beck exposes how Muslims are getting around the US Fair Housing Act and making Muslim only communities in America
‌
Muslim Developers are creating communities and then they create a monthly fee for all the homes, “75% of the service fee you're paying goes to the masjid posted 22 hours ago by PiratePatriotParrot 144 comments award share report block Wall Street Apes @WallStreetApes • 2d Glenn Beck exposes how Muslims are getting around the US Fair Housing Act and making Muslim only communities in America ‌ Muslim Developers are creating communities and then they create a monthly fee for all the homes, “75% of the service fee you're paying goes to the masjid — so

Muslim Developers are creating communities and then they create a monthly fee for all the homes, “75% of the service fee you're paying goes to the masjid — so your tax goes to the Mosque”
They say all potential buyers who see that fee aren’t okay with it, they don’t won’t want their money going to the mosque so no one but Muslims will buy the homes
This is fraud. Kind of like Chinese students and colleges. However, after looking at two types of properties to escape Illinois, restricted and unrestricted. We chose the restricted property, which is basically an HOA. There are some very nice unrestricted properties. However, they're either not easily accessible or you have neighbors that collect junk and live in trailers, or have both. For $350/year we get paved access to our property, which is plowed to the county road, and simple property restrictions. There are no Karen's complaining about colors, fencing, or the mailbox. However, the restrictions dictate what minimum size and type of house can be built, setbacks for outbuildings, etc. Basically, not all HOAs are bad. However, living under a Sharia HOA has to be the most restrictive use of an HOA that could ever happen. Pelosi_Halitosis 1 points 10 hours ago I never wanted to be in an HOA. However, after looking at two types of properties to escape Illinois, restricted and unrestricted. We chose the restricted property, which is basically an HOA. There are some very nice unrestricted properties. However, they're either not easily accessible or you have neighbors that collect junk and live in trailers, or have both. For $350/year we get paved access to our property, which is plowed to the county road, and simple property restrictions. There are no Karen's complaining about colors, fencing, or the mailbox. However, the restrictions dictate what minimum size and type of house can be built, setbacks for outbuildings, etc. Basically, not all HOAs are bad. However, living under a Sharia HOA has to be the most restrictive use of an HOA that could ever happen.
